body: I don't think we should snapshot the actions in the package into the annotations (since these can change). Instead, I would favor changing the `binding` field which is computed by the view to instead of being a Boolean type to a string which is the fully qualified name of the referenced package. Then a client can list all the packages and then fetch the actions via listing actions in the package namespace.

So if original actions or package are changed, would it be propagated to the bound package?
If we only keep FQN of original package in bound package, we cannot link original actions at CouchDB layer. Instead we can fetch all actions in original package and refine them to change the namespace to bound package at controller layer.

@dgrove-oss unfortunately its not, I suggest we move to a non-blocking redis client (the current one is blocking by design as it seems).

https://github.com/etaty/rediscala seems like a great fit (its correctly licensed as well).

Profiling of action invocations using the changes provided in this PR and without these changes. The action is a 34 MB zipped Node action. With WhiskActionMetadata changes: Without WhiskActionMetadata changes: First action invocation is a cache miss causing the controller to fetch the action from the DB. This means the code associated with the action is downloaded into the controller causing a spike in the used heap. Garbage collection is then performed to lower the used heap. The same action is then invoked three times without the previous heap increase since the action is now cached, which does not cause a fetch from the DB. Differences in the above graphs can been seen after garbage collection is performed. The non-modified controller contains a cache of the action's zip file causing that controller to consume more heap space than the modified controller. The difference in heap usage appears to be about 100MB after GC is performed. In order to avoid the large spike in heap usage incurred during a cache miss. We will need to turn the action code into a DB attachment, and only fetch that attachment when absolutely necessary.

If we can get bound actions from `actions` view directly it would be great, rather than get referenced actions multiple time for each binding and combine them to respond to the client.
I will more deeply look into current view and linked document.

The last invoker is per default only used for blackbox actions. The fraction of invokers used for blackbox invocations is configurable but it's always at least one invoker (today). Arguably, we can adjust that logic to be disablable.

Blackbox actions are actions based on user-provided docker images. Configuration is per environment variable and the code you posted.

We can adjust that logic, so you can completely disable that blackbox actions get their own invokers and are rather shared with all the other invokers.

Now simplified as suggested by @markusthoemmes.  With the state for the id assignment externalized to redis, there is no need to involve the controller at all.  Each invoker can self-assign ids on startup using redis for coordination.

@ningyougang you're bringing very good points, which may not be covered as part of this PR. This PR simply intends to build a couchDB image, pre-initialized for OpenWhisk, so that we don't have to run ansible to configure it.
@vvraskin thanks for updating docs and the default! LGTM
@misl if we just "fix" the swagger by adding types do you think the swagger-codegen will work?

I've looked at this a bit and I can't find a way to correctly specify the type here that works for all clients. You can specify a type of "object" that works for the Java client but fails some of the existing schema validation specs because a Swagger object is really a bit different than allowing any valid JSON type. If we upgrade to OpenAPI 3 here instead of Swagger 2 some of the new anyOf/oneOf keywords may help. Or, we could try to "fix" and/or try a newer version of swagger-codegen to see if this is an issue they've fixed.

A follow up after the short discussion we had during the community interlock. 

In case we need to support both UI and CLI based logs, I think it would be advantageous to stream the logs out to some internal bus/buffer (e.g. Reddis, Elasticsearch) and keep it there for a short period of time, say 10 mins. 
Then it would be possible either to keep the previous api or create a separate component just for log streaming (a concept similar to CF loggregator), so the CLI and other log consumers could connect to it and redirect them to whatever backend is needed.

That would provide more flexibility for the end users, say everyone is able to select a particular logging backend within one OpenWhisk provider versus an OW operator defining one backend for the whole deployment. However I‚Äôm not sure if an SPI concept allows to specify several implementations to run in parallel.

> In case we need to support both UI and CLI based logs,

I for one don't think this is a question of "if". The immediate availability of logs is critical for a fast dev/debug cycle. You cannot be at the mercy of your downstream log drain to make progress. I think this is a unique advantage of openwhisk and we should _not_ give that up.

A short retention period - tens of minutes or hours - makes sense. You only need to scan AWS/Lambda forums to see that among one of the complaints is that it takes a long time for logs to appear in cloudwatch.

Thanks for the comments @vvraskin and @rabbah - there is nothing prevent an SPI impl from achieving the requirements you mention: stream to ES or redis, making logs available "immediately" (by tuning your log driver collection process and waiting on the activation to finish and log collection to complete, as it does now). The concern I have is the nobody will agree that ES or splunk or xyz is the best place to store logs, and mostly I think everyone agrees that couchdb is not the best place. WDYT? Would it help if there was a different impl available? Its not clear how you'd like to see this PR changed.

I partially agree with @bbrowning. OpenAPI 3 has extra features (anyOf / oneOf) to better specify the KeyValue structure. But the Swagger CodeGen for OpenAPI 3 has not yet been released. I don't when this will be finished.

Swagger 2 however still can be used. It is possible to customize the underlying template. Since KeyValue is the only structure with type Object in there. There will probably be no side effects.

We did indeed. The first version of this PR included a latency penalty in the batching, which is why we started implementation in the invoker, where the penalty doesn't matter as much.

Want to wait for that and put it in this PR or are you fine with a second one improving on this?

I am still investigation whether sending arguments resutls in expected behaviour.
If you have an activation id, you can fetch by id. If you're using `wsk activation list` or using the UI, indexing the new activations may take a little bit of time.

Note that for actions not in packages, the URL is
`@POST("namespaces/{namespace}/actions/{actionName}")` and not this
`@POST("namespaces/{namespace}/actions/{packageName}/{actionName}")`

Maybe it's worth separating the two emits in the activation view into separate design docs - to allow for future changes to the by name indexing or alternate implementations without requiring a full reindex if the ddoc is changed. Thoughts @cbickel?
IMHO, we will want to avoid any breaking change to the REST API.. if that is what will happen with the new db view return value.

There are no breaking changes in this PR. And further changing the views to allow filtering activations by package _can_ be done without an API change. But I think there's more work to be done there to warrant a separate PR. That said, it is worth considering splitting the two views in the activations ddoc into their own ddocs, to permit independent changes in the future (either in this PR or a subsequent one).

A workaround to sidestep the problems of https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/issues/2788
The problem is that when an operator configures to use `runc`, it may not work correctly. This is what I tried to fix in  https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/pull/2799.

Since you're running armbian, I assume you're running on ARM hardware?

The error message you're getting is related to running binaries of x86 on ARM:

```
standard_init_linux.go:187: exec user process caused "exec format error"
```

Got no quick fix for that. Apparently, there are alpine base images for ARM specifically.

From what I recalled the point of using docker-runc/runc is performance, runc was the winner when we compared containerd vs. runc because pause/unpause with docker cli gave us terrible performance too many abstraction and management layers to do what we want when waking up a warm container
@markusthoemmes, from the Travis log, looks like controller failed to start.

I may have not done a good job of explaining the motivation for this PR.  

Getting a working docker-runc is touchy because you need an exact version match between the invoker container and the host.  @ddragosd is trying to fix that by mounting the binaries from the host.  I also experimented with that in the kube context, but just mounting the binaries isn't enough (at least on kube as made available on Bluemix). docker-runc from the kube worker node also has dependencies on libAppArmor, so there is more junk to drag in.  I haven't gotten that to work (and I'm not 100% sure it can be made to work reliably), so I thought bringing back the option to bypass runc to a lower performance option might be better to get some container reuse might be better than getting no reuse at all.   But maybe I'm wrong (is no reuse better than docker pause/unpase?)

Makes sense to me @jthomas; 3.8 is out.
I'm ok pinning to 3.x.

Should we fold this into the `DockerClient` to avoid needing to pass around the flag? The `DockerClient` could transparently use docker/runc then. That'd somewhat break abstraction but would be neater in terms of variable scoping.
